December 30, 1947.

Dear Miss Allard:

I send you a telegram yesterday morning:

"TAKE WARNING FOR YOU ARE BEST DAY INDIAN
THIS IS A TWO ROOM SCHOOL AND WE OFFER TEACHER WILL
BEGO—AIR MAIL LETTERS WILL FOLLOW THIS NEXT FALL."

The school at Best Bay which we are erecting
summer school is a two-room school, which was completed last
year and is in operation. The building is situated on the
school grounds and is connected by a path to the
post office, which is located across the street from the
railway station. The school is connected to the
railway station by a path and is situated on the C.P.R.
grounds.

The school is nine miles from the post office at Grassy, Ontario,
and is nine miles from the railway station at Glencoe, Ontario.
It is situated on the railway line between these two towns,
approximately two miles from the railway station, mostly
in the town of Grassy.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Dear Miss Richardson,

July 26th. With regard to a vacancy in one of our Indian Day Schools.

I note that you had one year of Peruit Teaching; are nineteen years of age and a Roman Catholic. It is unfortunate that you do not hold a Teaching Certificate, as new teachers would be entitled to an attractive salary on our new school. As it now stands, you will be entitled to a starting salary of $1080 per academic year. The present vacancy is for a Roman Catholic teacher at the Seine River Indian Day School, in which unfortunately this is a Father isolated and one on which we have always had a young man as teacher in previous years.

However, I am sending a copy of this letter to Mr. Lockhart, our Indian Superintendent, so that he may be able to offer you a school in the Port Arthur Agency. If you are interested in any of these schools, I would ask that you write him for further details.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Miss J.G. McArthur,
Swan Lake, Manitoba.

[Signature]
Sept. of Indian Education.
August 12, 1948.

Mr. T. G. Smith,
Superintendent, Indian Affairs,
Port Arthur, Ontario.

The Indian Day School,

Richardson, of Sioux Lake, has had an application from Miss Z. C., a teacher at the school. I would like to hear from you regarding her qualifications. To date we have not heard from you about Miss Richardson's qualifications. If you have no information available, I would suggest that you write directly to the Superintendent of Indian Affairs, giving her details of the applicant, her position, qualifications, etc. It would be appreciated if a copy of this letter could be sent here so that we can keep in touch with the filling of this position.

Miss Richardson has a master's teaching degree, and has 15 years of experience. She has already been employed by us for a starting salary of $1,000.00 an academic year.

Sincerely,

[Signature]

Superintendent of Education.
August 12th, 1948.

Dear Miss:

Copy sent to Mr. Lockhart.
December 3, 1946.

Hay River Indian Day School,

I am pleased to note that you will accept the position of teacher at the Hay River Indian Day School.

Would you please report for duty there on or before January 25th? You will have to be there by January 25th. You are thoroughly trained in practical work and I will leave this matter to your discretion.

You may take supplies in and these should have reached the school by the time you arrive.

The Department is prepared to pay your travelling expenses to Canadian Pacific Air Lines. You will have to see to Hay River. I understand that there are two flights a day over Hay River which you wish to know if you believe any arrangements can be made for this trip. I believe any arrangements can be made for this trip.

The furniture has been delivered for the school and should have arrived by now. If there is any other information you require, please let me know as soon as possible.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Mr. K. Bellavance,
C.I.T.I.S., Ontario.
December 3, 1948.

Dear Miss St. Pierre:

We have been able to obtain the services of a qualified teacher at the Cornwall Island East Indian Day School. However, there are two other vacancies which we require to be filled after the Christmas vacation.

One of these is at the Pic Indian D Y School which is three and one half miles from Heron Bay, Ontario on the C.P.R. Transcontinental Railway. This is a one-room school and there are some twenty children enrolled.

The second vacancy is at the Seine River Indian Day School near Grilly, Ontario. Unfortunately, this is a rather isolated school and we would prefer sending a male teacher to teach. In any event, I would be glad to hear from you if you are interested in either of these two positions.

I regret that we could not classify you as a Grade 2 teacher unless you produced evidence of holding a Teaching Certificate. Your starting salary as a Grade 1 teacher without any certificate and any experience would be $102, a teaching month with free house, fuel and light.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Henry,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Miss Florence St. Pierre,
Lemieux, Ontario.

DFW/KM.
December 3, 1948.

Dear Miss Toner:

We have been able to obtain the services of a qualified teacher at the Cornwall Island East Indian Day School. However, there are two other vacancies which we require to have filled after the Christmas holidays.

One of these is at the "Is Indian Bay" school which is three and one half miles from Heron Bay, Ontario, on the CPR Transcontinental Railway. This is a one-room school and there are some twenty children enrolled.

The second vacancy is at the Seine River Indian Day School near Grilly, Ontario. Unfortunately, this is a rather isolated school and we would prefer to send a male teacher to teach. In any event, I would be glad to hear from you if you are interested in either of these two positions.

I regret that we could not classify you as a Grade 2 teacher unless you produced evidence of holding a teaching certificate. Your starting salary as a Grade 1 teacher without any certificate or any experience would be $107.50 teaching month with free house, fuel and light.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Dept. of Indian Education.

Miss Sally Kathleen Toner,
Campbell's Bay, P.Q.,

Feline River Indian Day School.

Telegram: I had a long discussion with regard to this school. Union with Mrs. Kibby has been decided by Ottawa. Union certainly for us. We have decided to accept a teaching position near the city or Ottawa. Union certainly for us.

Replying to my wire concerning your promptness in replying to my wire concerning this teacher and we will continue to do everything possible to locate another teacher for you. If you have anyone in mind locally, please let me know at once so that we can arrange to advertise this position.

I note that the school is four miles from the railway station and six miles from the nearest store. Male teachers are very scarce but there is only one solution, that the teachers' quarters, from the photographs seems bedrooms and a kitchen. You might consider this fact as a self accommodation.

When Mr. Ballerena commenced teaching at the above named school we pointed out to him the various articles which could be supplied in the line of furniture, but as he did not request any additional furnishings.

There is very little furnishings in this school other than a blanket, spring, body worn mattress, stove, and folding wardrobe.

If we should be supplied with a couch, table, and possibly linoleum to make the living quarters more attractive, and possibly request school as you stated in your letter of December 19th this time; but as Mr. Zibbe would have the school only stayed a short time I think it might be the answer in keeping a full time teacher. We will, no doubt, be advised if she has accepted a school at an early date.

Re: 7316-456-1 (M)

Fort Frances, Ont., January 18, 1949.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Replying to your letter of the 8th instant, regarding furniture for the teachers' quarters at the Seine River Indian Day School attached to the school.

I wish to advise that there are two rooms, each about 10' x 12', used as a bedroom and the other as a living room. At present there is a bed, a chair, a table, and portable wardrobe in the bedroom. In the living room there is a couch, a table, and a portable wardrobe. The rooms are heated by a wood stove located in the living room.

The furniture is in good condition and sufficient for the needs of the teachers. However, there is a need for additional furniture, especially in the living room. It would be advisable to make the addition of a third room to the present quarters. The addition would provide more space for the teachers and their families.

J. P. Leckhart, Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

With reference to an advertisement which recently appeared in the "Chesire," National Catholic Weekly, demanding applications for the post of teacher at an Indian school near Fort Frances, Ontario, I wish to make application for such.

I am Irish by birth, having been in Canada since December 1946. I finished my classical college course in Ireland, graduating with Senior Matriculaton from the National University of Ireland.

In Canada, I studied for two years with the Basilian Fathers at St. Joseph's Seminary in Quebec, Quebec, and finished my first year Arts course having studied during the time pleased in Psychology, Natural Theology and in English. I also studied Greek, Latin and French.

At present I am a reporter with an English paper in Quebec City. I am fluent in French speaking, having picked up that tongue in Canada. I passed my exams in Latin, English, Irish, Arithmetic, Geometry, Algebra, Trigonometry, Calculus, Physics, Hebrew, Christian Art, Geography, Geology and Philosophy. I have some experience in teaching, having given private courses in English and French here.

I am 30 years of age, being born January 21, 1920 and am a
prestigious Catholic. I would like some kind of work that you offer, and am used to hardship if hardwork is entailed.

Please give my application careful consideration and oblige by replying.

Any information will gladly be given and plenty of recommendations are available.

Until I hear from you, Sir,

I remain,

Yours Very Sincerely,

[Signature]

[Name]

March 22, 1949.

Saline River Indian Day School.

I have for answer your application for the position of teacher at the Saline River Indian Day School. As the advertisement indicated we were anxious to obtain the services of a male teacher for this school and recently succeeded in doing so by distance telephone call from Mr. Indian Superintendent Bonnah at Cornwall, Ontario. The teacher at the Cornwall Island University in Switzerland has just obtained a scholarship to attend a Medical School there. This is a one-room school and I could only offer you quite a good position. With a second class teaching certificate over in September, you would be entitled to starting salary of $150.00 per month. We can place you elsewhere in a Catholic day school in Ontario next September. Would you please write immediately if you are interested in this position as I have already written to other teachers about it.

Indian Affairs, School Policy
As you are probably aware, we are doing everything possible to have official openings of all our new schools. We feel that it does not only serve to impress on the Indians the desire of the Department to bring to their children the best in educational facilities but it also helps in improving public relations with their local white neighbours. Members of parliament have assisted in opening several schools in the West, and you, no doubt, know that the Honourable Mr. Pearson officially opened our new two-room Indian Day School on the West Bay Reserve on Manitoulin Island, a few days ago.

Dear Father,

I am writing to you from [location]. I have been here for a few days now and everything seems to be going well. The weather has been quite pleasant and the people here are very friendly.

Dear Mr. Henry,

I am sending you letters of prospective teachers who have answered our advertisement made in the "Sneak." I am sending their letters, but we have kept copies of them. We wish to present you few of them for the day schools we have in our province, but we thought you would be interested in knowing those candidates for your other schools. We have written to them that you might yourself propose them a school.

We now propose:

1. For La Salle River day school:
   Mr. L. A. Rogers, if Mr. Demersville has given his resignation for the same school.

2. Mr. A. C. Budgena, for Waterken Reserve day school, decided to reopen the same school.

3. To have been told that Mr. P. Fong has from School's mention as teacher of White Fish Bay, if so, we propose Mr. A. T. Callaghan for that school.

Hoping that we will have more success than in the past with our candidate teachers,

I remain,

Yours truly,

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENT OF THE TREASURY

Re: Seine River Indian Day School - No. 45b

Marcel Henry Pilleaud has been appointed teacher of this school effective Sept. 15th, 1946, at a salary of $115.00 a teaching month. We enclose T.D. 1 Form and Cost of Living Bonus Form. Staff questionnaire will reach you shortly.

For Deputy Minister.
Ottawa, December 30, 1946.

Reverend Father:

The Department will accept Sigvard Petersen as teacher at the Seine River Indian Day School, effective January 1, 1947. It is noted that this teacher has had one year at the Ontario Agricultural College in Guelph but has had no teaching experience in Canada. However, due to the shortage of teachers we are prepared to accept his services at the rate of $118.00 a teaching month on a temporary basis until June 30, 1947. At this time we can review the teacher situation to ascertain if a more suitable teacher is available. During these months we will also have a more adequate opportunity to assess Mr. Petersen's teaching ability.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

With reference to a letter of the 16th instant from Miss Mary A. Beatty, in which she asks you to use your influence to obtain for her a diploma that was awarded by the Commis ioners of the World's Fair to the Indian School No. 2 on the Oreside Reserve for work done by the pupils of the school, I beg to say that I am unable to inform Miss Beatty more than that it seems improper to give diploma being given to her, but I propose to refer to the school.

In the first place, the work was done by the pupils, and the children in recognition of their work ought to receive the school credit.

If the children did the work during school hours, Miss Beatty cannot have no personal claim or any future which ought to be regarded as an incentive to encourage the children while at school. On the other hand, if the work was done either in or out of school or out of school
school hours, the special industry of the children in addition to their regular school routine ought to be acknowledged by the retention of the diploma in the school building.

Yours very truly,

Sir:

I have the honor to bring to your attention the present situation regarding the school facilities on the Onida Reserve. A new school was recently opened on consideration of the need for better educational facilities.

When I recently inspected the new school, I found that at Onida No. 2 School there were 51 children on the roll, though only 33 were eligible for school attendance and thus entitled to receive an education. However, due to the fact that the school is located in a remote area, many of the children have had to acquire additional burdens such as working during the harvest season or attending other schools further away.

The current school facilities are not sufficient to accommodate all the children who attend. In order to provide better educational opportunities, another school should be established closer to the center of the Reserve, where more children can benefit from its proximity.

I would appreciate your guidance on this matter and any suggestions you may have to improve the educational facilities on the Reserve.

Yours sincerely,

Sir:

Re: New School, Oneida Indian Reserve.

I would again wish to bring to your attention the very unsatisfactory school situation on the Oneida Reserve of this Agency and request your consideration to the early erection of another Day School on that Reserve. When I recently sent my estimates to the Department for the fiscal year 1932-33 (also for the past three years) I included an item of $4000.00 for such a building and this school is at present much more needed than ever before.

When recently compiling a list of those living on the Oneida Reserve, it was found counting all persons that there are 1067 inhabitants and over 130 children of school age, besides more than 80 pupils that are at present in Mount Elgin School and there are only two day schools with seats for 75 pupils to take care of this number of pupils, with the result that a large number of children are on the Reserve that are or have not been going to any school.

To-day I made an exception of these schools and found 38 pupils in Oneida No. 2 and 33 pupils in Oneida No. 2, and the teacher of Oneida No. 3, has had as high as 48 in one day and this means that 10 pupils have to double up in a single seat, this school has 51 on the roll. In company with Agent Moore, I visited the Oneida No. 2 and Oneida No. 3 Day Schools on the afternoon of May 19th, last. I found a good attendance at each school and there is no accommodation at either school for more pupils.

Another day school should be erected on this reserve as soon as funds will permit. There are 1,087 inhabitants on the Oneida Reserve and, approximately, 130 children who should be attending a day school. The two schools at present in operation only provide seating accommodation for about 73 pupils and, in addition, a large number of the children live at a considerable distance from these schools.

In view of the above conditions, the Agent is unable to enforce attendance owing to lack of accommodation.

Besides the children who attend the two schools at present, there are about 65 children from this reserve in the Mount Elgin Residential School.

It will be seen, therefore, that the building of at least one new school on the Oneida Reserve is really required.
Munsey, Ont., Feb. 12, 1955.

I would acknowledge receipt of your letter of February 7th regarding a monthly report on affairs at this agency.

I am going to submit for your consideration a number of suggestions that I would consider necessary for the future health and advancement of the Indians of this agency and while the whole will cost money, it may be good investment in the long run and would eliminate the belief of these Indians that they are a forgotten people and will receive no assistance from this office and the Department.

Re School conditions.

As has been reported to the Department many times the school situation on the Oneida Reserve of this agency has never been to the advantage of these people. For while we have a population of about 800 on the Caradoc side, we have four schools there, whereas on the Oneida side with a population of nearly 1000 we only have two schools and the result is that we have more pupils than can be accommodated and have had to place nearly 60 Oneida children in residential schools, many of whom could have remained at home if day schools were available. The Oneida Reserve really should have two more day schools and in this way the children of that reserve could be brought on a par with the children of the Munsey and Chippewa Bands, who are progressing more rapidly than their neighbors.

By the erection of two new schools on the Oneida reserve it would allow a teacher in the vicinity of 30 pupils each and due to the Oneidas retaining their Indian habits so much this number is all that a teacher could give attention to for many pupils start school without knowing a word of English and the teachers have a hard and trying time with beginners. There are children on the Oneida reserve that have never been in a school due to lack of accommodation and are neglected by the part of the present. If more schools were available drastic action would be taken by this office to force all children to attend and the truancy act enforced, which is not possible at the present time. School conditions on the Munsey and Chippewa reserves are in a very good state at present.

If new schools are being contemplated at this agency I would suggest that consideration be given to having a teachers residence attached to the school, so that school garden supervision could be given, also close attention to government property.

Indian Agent.

DESCRIPTION OF SITE AND CONDITIONS; SUBMIT PLAN; NORTH POINT;
NATURE OF SOIL, DRAINAGE REQUIREMENTS AND ANY OTHER PARTICULARS:
The top soil is a fairly heavy sandy loam with the subsoil of gravel and at about a fifteen foot depth it is equal. Building should face North east.

All Indian residences near proposed school have good surface wells and agent considers water could be obtained by the same method on the school lot. Indian labour would be employed to dig this well.

Two outside toilets should be erected.

HEATING SYSTEM: TYPE OF FURNACE OR BOILER; FUEL.

Hot air heating with coal burning furnace.

LIGHTING SYSTEM: SOURCE OF POWER; SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS.

BUILT-IN EQUIPMENT REQUIRED: BLACKBOARD AREA; CUPBOARDS, ETC.

Blackboard space should be provided at front of building and on one side.

SHIPPING INSTRUCTIONS FOR MATERIALS: NEAREST SHIPPING POINT

LOCAL TRANSPORTATION FACILITIES TO SITE, ETC.

That the tender of John Alexander Drake, Strathroy, Ont., was in accordance with plans and specifications and was the lowest tender received and that the necessary security deposit has been furnished by him.

Memorandum:

Schools.

I wish to inform you that while at the Caradoc Agency, I visited the new school on the Oneida Reserve.

The teacher brought to my attention that the two drains in the classrooms were not working. This can be readily understood as there is no drain away from the school. The engineers had been under the impression that the gravel soil would take care of the drainage from these drains. It is evident, however, these drains should not be used.

The teacher said she required the following:
A cupboard should be built on the wall at the end of the blackboard; height, 4 ft., by 6 ft., by 1 ft. Also two small cupboards are needed in the classrooms to store the lunches the children bring with them to school. These need not be larger than 3 ft. by 6 ft., by 1 ft., and should contain one shelf. Each classroom should be equipped with a bench on which to place basins where the children could wash their hands. Two more basins are required, and in addition, two pails are needed for the waste water. At the present time, the water is being thrown out the window.

The well is practically dry as only at times can the teacher get any water out of it.

If the Agent were authorized to have the cupboards built, he could have an Indian on the Reserve do the work.

General Superintendent

Dear Sir: Attention Mr. R.A. Hoey,

In acknowledging receipt of your letter 7-5-5 of December 20th, concerning the report made by Inspector Smith on his recent visit to the new school No. 1, Indian Day School, I would advise that on Nov. 14th Mr. Smith mentioned the drains and pump when he made a quick visit to this office and November 16th I visited the school and with a lead pencil opened the drains and allowed the water to go away. These drains are the ordinary floor type and sediment had gathered around the holes in the drain plate. To eliminate this in future two slop pails were supplied so that no refuse need be pored down these drains.

The pump at the school like all others in the close locality of the school and on account of the very mild and dry fall, did go dry at times and this well being new and built in the dry season has not reached its full capacity and ten pails will dry it at times and it is hoped that during the wet season it will fill up and give a sufficient supply for all needs. It was also learned that when the local Indian wells went dry that they early in the morning and before the teacher and caretaker were on the job, did go to the school well for their daily water supply and when the teacher would wish water for the school and residence the Indians had drained it. This well should provide plenty of water after it has been given a chance to establish a reserve supply during the wet season.

Dear Sir:

Please be advised that it will be necessary to install tile for drainage purposes around the foundation of the new Oneida No.1 Indian Day School and the cost of material and labour will run in the vicinity of $100.00.

The last few days we have had heavy rain falls and the water is three inches deep in the basement of this new school and it has been necessary to engage a man to bail this water out each day and to allow the water to continue to run into the basement will affect the flooring and foundation of the school. The need of a tile drain around this school was brought to the attention of the Engineer when the school was built and it was thought that as there was a thickness of gravel under the foundation that no tile would need to be installed, which has now been found to be in error.

Six hundred and twenty-four inch field tile are needed which will cost $15.50 purchased locally. One hundred and seventy feet of these tile would be used around the building and the other four hundred and fifty will be used for an outlet to the bank of the River Thames. The cost of installing these tile will be in the vicinity of $75.00 to $85.00 and an advance of this amount should be made this office to pay the labour.

Your early attention and authority to install this drain is requested.

Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

Re - Oneida No. 1 Indian Day School.

I have your memorandum of April 21st quoting a letter received from your Indian Agent in which he states that it is necessary to install drainage tile around the foundation of the above school at a total cost of approximately $100.

In this connection I might say that the Engineer in charge of the construction of this School does not know of any reason why there should be water in the basement as the usual waterproofing precautions were taken.

I am quoting herewith the Chief Engineer's remarks in this connection:

"I might say that before construction was begun, information received in connection with the site indicated that subsurface soil conditions provided good natural drainage. This was confirmed by our supervising engineer, and the contractor. Weeping tile drainage was, therefore, not considered necessary. The foundation walls were covered with two coats of tar pitch, as waterproofing; and, as the building was twenty-five feet above the water level of the Thames River, it is difficult to state the reason for water infiltration as reported."
It is of course most undesirable that in the new schools there should be trouble with water in the basements, and our Architects have been instructed to give consideration to providing for drainage, not only around the foundation walls but also from the basement floor itself, in future schools.

Mr. Dudley, of our Architectural staff, will be in Western Ontario in a few days and we are asking him to make an inspection of the Oneida school.

Director.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle:
Re - Indian Day School,
Onigami Reserve, Ont.

With further reference to our memorandum of the 8th instant, I may say that when in the vicinity, Mr. Dudley visited the above building on the 11th instant and reported as follows:

- The basement foundation walls are in sound condition and show no signs of water seepage or damage. Upon investigation with the school teacher, it appears that during the flooding of the basement this spring, the water entered through the wall stonework lines which obviously are construction joints formed by interruptions during the pouring of the concrete slab.

As the water level in the walls in the district was exceptionally high this year, it would appear that the flooding of the school was due to water in the soil and can only be prevented by rapid drainage of the soil around the building. It is considered that the installation of a 6" drainage tile drain around the building will provide the drainage required to prevent flooding under such circumstances.

Enclosed hereto is a plan in duplicate, for transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch, for their information and for their Agent in carrying out the proposed work.

Respectfully submitted,

August 26th, 1941

Dear Sir:

I would beg to advise that the newly appointed teacher of the Oneida No. 1 Indian Day School at Caradoc Agency, Mrs. Margaret Wallace, has written to this office requesting that a sanitary closet be installed for use in the residence. I have been informed that this teacher has one child of her own who will be living in the residence with her and apparently neither Mrs. Wallace nor the child wish to use the same toilets as the Indian pupils attending the school. The estimated cost of a sanitary closet complete with pipes, elbows etc., would, with installation, be about $12.00.

Mrs. Wallace, the teacher, also requests that the Department provide her with a garage for her car. There is no garage at this school as a similar request from the former teacher of this school was not approved in your letter 7-5-1 of Sept. 13th, 1938. The new teacher intends to keep her car at the school throughout the term and is of the opinion that a garage should be supplied. A garage of metal construction such as was supplied at Lower Muncy and Back Settlement schools would, in my opinion, be most satisfactory and the estimated cost of same would be $100.00.

I would wish to be advised if the Department approves of the above expenditures and if so, instructions regarding purchase of same would be appreciated.

Mrs. Wallace has also asked for permission to occupy the residence about one week in advance of the opening of school on October 1st and I would wish to be advised if this would meet with the approval of the Department. An early reply would be appreciated so that I may inform the teacher of the Department's decisions.

Your obedient servant,

M. W. McCracken
In Charge
Caradoc Agency.

Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,

Ottawa, September 2, 1941.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of August 28, you may expend an amount of $12.00 in installing a sanitary closet in the teacher's residence at the Oneida No. 1 Indian Day School. You may also allow Mrs. Wallace to occupy the teacher's residence about a week in advance of the opening of the school on October 1.

It has not been our practice in recent years to provide a garage at any Indian day school. Under these circumstances, favourable consideration cannot be given to the request of Mrs. Wallace for a garage at the Oneida No. 1 School.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo with reference to the erection of a garage at the Oneida No. 1 School.

At the present time it is definitely not our policy to provide a garage for a teacher or an Indian day school. We will readily appreciate that if we build a garage at one school we would have similar requests from practically all of them.

Since Mrs. Wallace was appointed teacher of this school the Government has provided a cost-of-living bonus and, as a result, Mrs. Wallace will receive $15 more salary than she originally expected. Besides, she has very comfortable living quarters and I do not feel that it is our responsibility to erect a garage simply because she purchased a car for her personal use.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. G. W. Down, Indian Agent, Muncey, Ont.

I have before me reports on the No. 1, No. 2 and No. 3 Oneida Indian Day Schools. Inspector Smith, in his report on the No. 2 School, states:

"Three or four fence posts in front of the school have been broken off and the fence is practically down."

A reference to the No. 1 School reads:

"The doors of both the closets are off and lying on the ground. The teacher states that they were off on the opening of the school in September, were put on once and were again taken off. Nothing has been done about it since."

The officials here realise that our agents are experiencing a certain amount of difficulty in securing the help necessary to undertake repairs at Indian day schools and agency buildings throughout the Dominion. Nevertheless, the inspector's reference to the condition of the closets at the No. 1 School is somewhat disturbing. I have always taken the position that instruction in cleanliness and neatness is just as important at an Indian school as the teaching of any other subject, and I have been particularly insistent, throughout my stay with the Department, that outdoor closets should be kept clean, comfortable and in a good state of repair. Such work, I feel, should be fundamental in our educational scheme of things. It would be very much appreciated, therefore, if you would take the steps necessary to have these repairs undertaken at the earliest possible date. If Indians smile have formed the habit of removing these doors or in any way impairing departmental property, the matter should be discussed with the R.C.M.P.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Indian Affairs' Branch,
Dept of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter dated December 16th in reference to Public School Inspector Smith's report on Oneida Indian Day Schools. I regret that these adverse reports are necessary and feel that much correspondence could be saved if the inspector conducted visits once or twice a year, contact our local Office and discuss problems to our mutual benefit. I am however, sure that you will appreciate the difficulties that I am, with many others, experiencing in securing labour for the many jobs that need attention.

In regard to the fence posts at No. 2 I have to advise that every year and throughout the year, there is a certain amount of repairing of fences due to the fact that they get off and let the wire down. It is regretted that Mr. Smith should have called at the school before we had a chance to repair them. It is most difficult in these strained days, to get any of our work done and we usually have to wait the other fellow's convenience. I have been waiting four months for electrical repairs to Agency buildings and each time I contact the electrician I am told "in due time".

As to the toilets at No. 1 both the teacher and I have become very much concerned about the wanton destruction of not only school property but personal property. Some person or persons deliberately slashed the tires of the teacher's automobile and generally played havoc with the inside. All efforts so far to learn the names of the guilty parties have failed. The pupils deny any knowledge of such destructiveness and I believe they are telling the truth. It is thought to be the work of a gang of boys of sixteen or seventeen. We no sooner get things repaired than they are torn down again. Whoever is responsible for this wantonness is operating not only within the confines of the Reserves but also in the village of Munczy. Our Departmental Nurse's private car has been stolen and damaged twice; stores and houses have been broken into and articles stolen. Three weeks ago 32 chickens were stolen from the Mt. Elgin Residential School. Two weeks ago Mr. Lockwood's store was broken into and $25 worth of goods stolen. One week ago three garages were broken into and windows smashed in cars; and two pairs of shoes stolen from Mr. Lockwood's car. These shoes were recovered, scattered throughout the Reserve. Even the Chippewa Council Hall received attention, windows were
broken and electric fixtures literally torn from the walls. Several Indian homes have been entered and goods and supplies taken. It is not only discouraging but disgusting, when everything possible is being done for their comfort, to have them do such things. The doors of the closets have been put back on three times, the last time with bolts instead of screws.

The R.C.M.P. and Provincial Police have been working on these reported cases and it is thought that the same persons are responsible both on and off the Reserves. All this may have no bearing on this particular school but we think it has. In any case it will serve to give you some idea of the character and minds of some of these people and when I say that the Cariboo Agency is the toughest assignment I have ever had, it is no exaggeration. However, you can be assured that during my term of administration everything possible is being, and will be, done to keep all buildings in a good state of repair with special emphasis placed on cleanliness.

In conclusion may I ask, "Have I, at all times, the authority to go ahead and make all minor repairs without first submitting the requirements to Ottawa for consideration and approval?"

Geo. W. Down,
INDIAN AGENT.

Fulton, Stratford, Ontario, has been successful in bringing to a conclusion all complaints received, both on and off the Reserve. The following being a brief summary:

Lloyd JURCH (Indian) Juvenile, Amosybuta, Sec. 3 Juvenile Delinquents Act, B.C. & Theft (Please see report dated 7-12-43). This Indian was convicted and placed on probation for B.C. & Theft, from Lockwood's General Store, Amosybuta, Samuel SLAM (Indian) Childless aged 16, Theft of Chickens Sec. 370 C.C. of C. (Please see report dated 7-12-43). This Indian together with Lloyd JURCH and Hubert GROSSBICK (Indians) were arrested by the writer and later convicted for the Theft of thirty chickens, from the Mount Algoma Indian Residential School. In addition, JURCH was also convicted by the Court Provincial, on several charges of attempted theft of automobiles and the breaking and entering of one private home and one private garage, all these offenses taking place in the village of Amosybuta. I might point out that the 12 pairs of shoes that were stolen from Mr. J. Lockwood's car, were recovered by the writer and Prov. Sgt. Fulton, within 50 yards of the car from which they were stolen, and not scattered throughout the Reserve, also that the only car window that was broken, was the no draft window on Mr. Lockwood's car.

No complaints of any kind of lawlessness has been received at this Detachment since the arrest and conviction of SLAM, JURCH and GROSSBICK, who no doubt were responsible for most if not all of the lawlessness referred to by Mr. Down.

In connection with the reference made by Mr. Down, of the theft on two occasions of Mrs. Morrison's private car, I might point out that an attempt was made to steal this car on two occasions by Lloyd JURCH, but he only managed to get the car approximately 500 yards from the garage on both occasions having backed the car out of the garage on the starter, and then making an attempt to cross the ignition wires to get it started. Two Indian homes were also entered by JURCH; however, the complainants, Mrs. Dennis Fisher and Mrs. Mary Delaney, did not lay any charges; these cases however, were brought to the attention of the Magistrate, who took them into consideration when passing sentence.

Oneida No. 1 School

The urinal is broken loose in boys' toilet, the pump is not working and door knobs on two outside doors are not in working order.
Ottawa, 5 November 1946.

Mr. G.W. Down, Indian Agent,
MUNCEY, Ontario.

The following is an extract from a recent report received from the Public School Inspector regarding the Oneida No. 1 School:

"The urinal is broken loose in the boys' toilet, the pump is not working and the door knobs on the two outside doors are not in working order."

Please make immediate arrangements for the necessary repairs.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
I have your letter of November 5th, with regard to repairs at the Onside No. 1 School, and note the Inspector's remarks. I am reminded of another Inspector who, a few years ago, after a urinal had been installed and operating successfully for several years and was still not giving trouble, reported to Ottawa that the hole was not large enough. I took two men out to look over the situation and do whatever was necessary and we were all three definitely of the opinion that it was a matter of "opinion". It would appear that some Inspectors are more concerned with doodle-bugs than they are with the education of children and that they have not yet awakened to the realization of material and labour short supply. However, being what I am, a civil servant which is almost a criminal offence in this Caradoc Agency, and the continual petty complaints, many of which by-pass this Office, I sometimes feel like "blowing the lid".

I am wondering if the immensity and responsibility of the work at the Caradoc Agency is realized and appreciated, especially as I am without a Farm Instructor and a clerk? However, in view of the defects mentioned and I can assure you, as is always the case, everything is being done to keep all buildings in repair; but under present short supply conditions, for which I am not responsible, it is annoying to have responsible men report such things to Ottawa. The pump he mentions was away being repaired. If the Inspector would discuss such minor trivial repairs with local officials, much annoyance, correspondence and respect for his views would be saved.

With the new school, new road, repairing the old school, heating buildings, supervising and operating the Mt. Elgin Farm lands, individual Indian farm requirements, murders, vandalism, robberies, and an ever increasing Office routine, might I suggest that the Inspector be advised that in future such matters
should be taken up with local Officials who will at all times co-operate and make necessary repairs as soon as possible.

Yours truly,

Geo. W. Down,
INDIAN AGENT.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dep't of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Inspection Report
Oneida No. 1
Indian Day School

This is a comparatively new frame school (Teacher's Residence attached), with full basement and hot air furnace, built in 1938.

Since completion there has been nothing done in the way of interior or exterior re-decorating. You may therefore expect that it begins to look shabby; in other words it is past due for complete re-decorating.

I also examined the floor closely which appears to be softwood, and is wearing badly. The only thing to save it would be a covering of battleship linoleum or some other such material. The area, by measurement, including the two annexes, is approximately 850 square feet. These, of course, are major jobs and will have to be considered in the very near future.

The minor repairs, which I am endeavouring to have completed before school reopens, are as follows—

Necessary replacement of window glass
Rehanging of door in basement
Repair of outside approach handrails
Repair of outside steps
Repair of doors on toilets
New, complete, lock set on classroom door
One gallon paint for new woodwork

and I trust my action meets with your approval.

With regard to major repairs please do not ask for estimates. At present I cannot find any person interested enough to drive into Muncey to even look at a job. I can only suggest that whatever you approve that I be given authority to proceed, and I will do my best to get these jobs under way.

Geo. W. Down,
INDIAN AGENT.
Muncey, Ontario,
July 28, 1947.

Two or three years ago Mr. Doucet, in my company, inspected all Day Schools of the Caradoc Agency and he will perhaps recall conditions and some of the comments and suggestions at that time. Since then we have passed through a difficult period and I realize that our buildings, owing to many circumstances particularly shortages of materials, shortages of labour and insufficient funds—all of which were beyond our control, did not improve with the years. Even when small allotments were provided it was difficult to proceed beyond the hopeful stage. It was with this thought in mind that I recently visited all schools and made thorough inspections as to major, and immediate minor repairs. I also feel that I should make a statement as to River Settlement School, and Back Settlement School.

Individual reports are attached, hereto. In submitting them it must be kept in mind that I cannot promise anything in the way of any repairs. Labour shortage and material shortages are still factors to be considered but I will do my best if given authority to proceed.

Geo. W. Down,

Chapleau, August 6th, 1934.

Sir:

I herewith beg leave to enclose letter received from the Rev. Canon Prewer, relative to the building of small school buildings on the Letagami & Bleas Reserves for the Indians.

On my annuity trip I went into this matter fully with these Bands and they are very anxious that something should be done along the lines suggested that their children might be educated and I wish to recommend that the Department give these requests serious consideration.

These bands have become fairly well established and the move towards a school would encourage them to remain on the reserves instead of scattering all over the North country as they have been in the habit of doing the past number of years and getting broken up in several small little groups with no self appointed leader, and which is very bad practice both socially and otherwise for the different bands and were a small school erected there would be suitable teacher to teach the children it would be an incentive for them to remain on the reserve and allow the men to go out and trap and hunt, which is the only manner of making a living these Indians in this Agency seem to know.

Waiting your instructions I beg to remain,

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) T. J. Godfrey.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Orig. on 65-3-1.

The Indians on the Matagamah Reserve, situated
17 miles north of the village of Gogama, on the C. N. Railway,
ask for a building to be erected to serve as a school-house,
with a room attached for the accommodation of a teacher, as
expeditiously as possible.

They point out the fact that they have quite
willingly conformed to the Department's regulation and have
moved back on to their reserve, not without a good deal of
labour and sacrifice, and that in the very near future there
will be something like 30 families settled there, where most
of them have already constructed tidy little log houses and
cleared and planted their gardens.

There are 25 children of school age resident on the
reserve, and by next spring this number will be augmented
by 10 more. They agree to do a great deal of the work them-
selves, voluntarily, and propose that a log building be
erected, but lumber for flooring and other purposes will be
required, together with windows and doors, and the whole
cost may mount up to about $750.00.

They would like the sanction of the Department to
this proposition at once and for work to commence before the
weather becomes too cold and the season becomes too far
advanced, so that the building is completed before they have
to leave for their trap-lines. Most of the families, with
children, will reside on the reserve all winter, while the
men attend to their trapping.
February 5, 1935.

Memorandum:

MR. O.R.B.,-

METTAGAMI: To assist in the erection of school building with rooms attached for living accommodation of teacher - $750.00

There are 26 children of school age. In the erection of a building, the Indians have agreed to do a great deal of the work themselves, voluntarily, and they propose that a log building be erected, but lumber for clearing, windows, doors and certain other material will have to be supplied. This school is in the Chapleau Agency, and Mr. Agent Godfrey would, no doubt, be able to arrange for a suitable site. He would also arrange with the Indians to do the greater part of the labour. It might be necessary to use the services of a White foreman.

The Anglican Missionary for the district reports that the Indians themselves state a log building for school purposes would be satisfactory and that, as they will do a great part of the labour, voluntarily, the amount above stated would be sufficient to carry out the work.

This reserve is situated 17 miles north of the village of Gogama, on the C. N. R.

Funds for the purpose, to the above amount, are included in the Estimates for the fiscal year 1935-36.

Dear Sirs:

When Mr. Indian Agent Godfrey made his treaty payments this year, on the 24th of June, at Ross and at Matagamah, he advised both bands that your department had finally acceded to their requests for the erection of day schools on their reserves.

The Indians were greatly pleased with the department's decision, and agreed to start at once to clear the sites and get out the heavy foundation timber, slopes and cedar posts, and received permits from the Forestry Branch for the burning of all brush etc. The Don Larkes Lumber Company at Ross loaned the people a horse to pull the stumps and the logs, and the Poupoura Lumber Co., of Gogama offered a team for the Matagamah people's use.

Owing to the fact that Mr. Godfrey is so far removed from the source from which material for building would have to be secured, he asked me to try and get an estimate of the amount of material required and the approximate cost.

Keeping in view the requirements as laid down by the Provincial Education Act, as to light and floor space for schools to accommodate an enrollment of from 25 to 30 pupils I was forced to the conclusion that a building 30x30 would be required, with an entrance to serve as a cloak room, and an annex at the rear 20x12 to serve as quarters for a teacher would be necessary.

I find after getting in estimates of costs of material, and by employing one capable man as carpenter, that such a building could possibly be erected for somewhere about $1400.00. It would mean however that some of the work would have to be done free of cost by the Indians themselves. The cost of freighting in the materials, especially to Matagamah, a distance of 17 miles will come somewhat high. I have already got an estimate of this cost, and I believe it will take fully two weeks before all material can be assembled, which will then be summer quite far advanced. I have hoped the buildings would be in readiness for use by Sept 15th.

I have been in communication with Mr. Godfrey regarding this matter and he advised me that he had no further word as to what the Dept. was prepared to do. In his thought it is advisable for me to take up the matter with you.

I have a plan drawn of the building it is proposed to erect, which I am enclosing, but I have not gone into detailed specifications.

The height of the walls would be 8' ft. It shall be of frame, sheeted inside and out with ship-lap cove ed over with asphalt paper, inside, outside with 'pop siding and inside with wainscoting up to windows and the upper part with V joint lumber. The roof would be sheathed with ship-lap and covered with No. 1 roofing material, which would be of brick.

I am most anxious to see these buildings erected, as I expect to have to go West as far as Calgary in September and would like to know that they are an assured fact before I leave. This is my excuse for taking up the matter with you. Believe if your department is agreeable, that I can guarantee a very strongly constructed and serviceable building for the price mentioned, and shall await with expectation upon your decision.

Faithfully yours,

Dear Sirs:

For the past several months, our Board of Trade has investigated the need of a school for the Indian children on the Mattagami Indian Reserve and we find that there are at least thirty children of school age residing on this Reserve who never had any schooling.

It is very unfair to these children that they should be raised illiterates and without moral training through no fault of their own.

A school on this Reserve could be built at a very low cost by utilizing hewn timber for the construction which is available close to the site where such school would be built and as far as labour is concerned we are sure that the Indians would be prepared to supply this without cost to the Department.

Until four or five years ago, some of these Indian families were living in Gogama, where their children were privileged to attend our schools here, but since they have been compelled to reside on the Reserve, they are deprived of this advantage.

We hope that your Department will give this matter its serious consideration.

Very truly yours,

Dear Sir,

I beg leave to acknowledge receipt of Official letter No.65-3, I of February 21st, relative to the building of a school for the Ketagami Indians on the Ketagami reserve.

I have read carefully the letter attached from the President of the Board of Trade a young business man who no doubt sees the necessity for a school for these Indian children, and this situation has for a number of years been brought to the attention of the Department and they have acknowledged the necessity of a school and have considerable data on the matter and had I felt decided to go ahead with the matter this summer and the Indians were quite glad to know that they might expect some action on this matter and if Mr. Kathe, has changed his mind led the Department to feel that the Indians could do as he says he is to my personal knowledge entirely mistaken so far as he says in paragraph 3 that a school could be built on the Reserve at a very low cost using Indians and are sure the Indians would supply labour free of cost, and my reply to this is that a make shift building such as the Indians could erect would not be suitable, and I do not believe the Indians would work without wages as they have to keep their families, in fact I believe these Indians are not good axe men and I am afraid after the timber were hewn even with good axe men the building would cost more than if a proper building were erected and one which would meet with the approval of the Department.

I can understand the Board of Trade wanting to do something so that these thirty or forty children can secure an education, but a building such as they would be able to build would hardly meet the situation unless men who thoroughly understood the work were brought in to do the work, and one looks at the cabins that they have erected on the Reserve for their own homes where there is plenty of good timber would convince any person that these men would only make a mess of the building and while I am wishing to see a building erected for these people I believe a building of plain structure should be erected so that it might suit the situation as well as being an example of neatness and not too costly and one that would pass ordinary educational regulations.

There is a Saw Mill just a few miles from the Reserve where all the rough lumber could be secured at a reasonable cost, but all finished lumber would have to be shipped in, and I would recommend that the matter of building a squared timber building not be taken seriously as these Indians as I have mentioned are not axe-men and the job if done by them would not be much of a success.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

It is almost impossible to get a sketch of the lot where the proposed school is to be erected as there is no way of getting to the reserve short of a five day trip other than by plane, but I have asked the Chief of the band to forward to me a sketch of the lot.

The lot is on the shore of the Matagami River back about 200 yds. from the river on a field of ground which has been cleared by the Indians; the soil is of a sandy nature and with plenty of drainage and the building could face the river which is South East of the lot the wooded portion being to the North & West.

There is quite a large clearing between the school site and the wooded portion, but on my trip to the reserve last month I requested the Indians to clear more land for the protection of the buildings as well as the school when it is erected and they agreed to do so as soon as the snow went away in the spring.

Dear Sir,

I beg leave to report on the condition of the Metagami Reserve Day School after the forest fire that passed through there.

When in paying Annuity money I had the chance to thoroughly examine the school, and it is simply due to the good work of the Indians that it is standing at all; the fire went all around it, and by carrying pails of water from the well the Indians kept the building from any other damage than that caused by smoke and heat.

It had been well cleaned up by some of the Indian women and I am enclosing some small accounts in their favour.

The paint all round the building had been badly scorched, is all curled off and will have to be scraped off and repainted. I might say here, that although from the specifications I have in the office, that the building should have had three coats of paint when built, I would say from my own experience that it is doubtful if it had two; there is no sign of any priming coat; even some places that the fire did not affect so much is also peeling off, and it looks as though a coat of gloss paint was all that it got; however, it will now take about five gallons of flat white and five gallons of gloss white to give it sufficient protection from the weather.

I have enquired here and find that I can get a good grade of paint delivered to Gogama at the price of $3.90 per gallon, brushes also will be needed if the Indians are to do the work, of which I think
they are quite capable, and I would suggest the purchase of four brushes, 4" wide at a cost of $1.95 each.

If I had your authority to purchase these items, also to hire Indians to do the work, I think I can arrange to get it done satisfactorily; I intend visiting this reserve again about the end of the month, and could make any necessary arrangements then.

Please let me know what you desire to have done here, as it certainly should have some protection while the weather is warm.

Your obedient servant

Re; Mattagami School repairs.

When at this school recently I found that the lining of the firebox in the furnace was pretty well burnt out, and not in a fit state for this winter's use.

Ottawa, December 2, 1947.

Reverend Sir:

I have for answer your letter of November 28th. Unfortunately the Department some years ago decided against the policy of providing money for Christmas treats. At that time we were being overwhelmed with requests for assistance and in some instances the Indians could have raised a little money themselves to provide for their treats.

In certain of our more isolated schools we are providing a small grant for noon day lunch. A search of our files seems to indicate that although your school is receiving a supply of vitalized biscuits you are not in receipt of this grant for the purchase of lunch supplies. Therefore, we are prepared to make a grant of up to $3.00 a month for November and December of 1947 and January, February and March of 1948 for this purpose.

It is understood that your school supplies have gone forward and should have reached you by now. We are arranging to forward a football, a softball and softball bats (the latter for use in the Spring). We do not provide boxing gloves or skates. We are also requisitioning for some crepe paper which I hope will reach you in time.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Aupt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sirs:

Goodwins Limited of this City, brought to our attention in Montreal, the following quantities of double desks and seats:

- 3 #2 double desks
- 7 #3 Double desks
- 4 #4 double desks
- 2 #5 double seats

These desks and seats are uncrated and unmarked. Goodwins Ltd. told us that they were for Albany. We presume that these goods are the ones mentioned in your folio 30297/4 and in our letter to you dated April 12th.

We tried to refuse delivery of these desks, as we do not wish to transport them uncrated to James Bay. Goodwins Ltd answered that they were unable to keep them any longer in their store, and absolutely refused to pack same. The goods were left on our hands under the strongest protest.

We have them stored momentarily in our office at Montreal.

We wish to ask you to give your instructions to Goodwins Limited, to have them taken back at once and properly packed. If these desks and seats are not crated securely by the above date, inside of a few days, we will not transport them to James Bay, as we do not wish to see them smashed to bits on our steamer, during the trip North.

Furthermore, we beg to advise you that we will ship them to Ottawa, if Goodwins Ltd go on refusing to crate them or to take them off our hands.

We have no place for them here, their storage on the wharf uncrated being, of course, out of the question.

Very truly yours,

Revillon Freres Trading Co., Limited.

Ottawa, July 6, 1922.

Dear Father Guy:

Your letter of the 28th ultimo has been received, enclosing accounts to the amount of $2667.49 for expenses incurred up to March 14, 1922, by the management of the Fort Albany Boarding School, in connection with the moving of the building to a new site and alterations and additions.

The total amount provided in our Estimate for the current fiscal year for this purpose is $8,000. It is necessary, in order to satisfy the requirements of the Auditor General, and to carry out the established rule of the Department in making payments of this kind, that a certificate be received that the work of moving the building and the completion of the additions and repairs has been satisfactorily performed, before payment of the amount appropriated for the purpose can be made.

Kindly have the authorities in charge of the work forward properly itemized accounts, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of any material required and for the labour employed. Receipts should be obtained in duplicate for the amounts paid out to the individual labourers employed, and these should show the number of days each was engaged and the amount paid per day.

As soon as we are assured that the work has been satisfactorily completed and the accounts received in proper order, payment will be made up to the amount provided by Parliament for the purpose.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. Job Guy, O.M.I.,

My Dear Mr. Scott:

As a sequel to our conversation of recent date, I take the liberty to request the reconsideration of the decision contained in your letter of July 6th, regarding the amount of $2567.49 for expenses incurred up to March 14th, 1922, by the management of Fort Albany Indian Boarding School, in connection with the moving of the building to a new site and reconstruction of same.

Your letter states that in order to satisfy the requirements of the Auditor General and to carry out the established rule of the Department, it is necessary, in order to reduce the amount provided for in the Estimates ($6,000.00) that a certificate proving completion of the work be filed with the Department.

Kindly allow me to tell you that a grant was asked from the Department on account of our inability to meet such an expenditure and therefore we expected the amount appropriated to be paid as the work was going on. Though our men have been working steadily during the present year we do not expect the work to be completed before the Fall of 1923; consequently the amount voted for would not be used for the purpose intended during the fiscal year (1922-23). As His Grace Bishop Hallé already impressed upon you the transfer and rebuilding of the school are works of pressing necessity.

I understand that the Department is governed by rules established upon experience and wisdom. However, do you not think that in a case like the present one an exception should be made? I leave the whole matter to your judgment and, as you are perfectly conversant with the situation of Fort Albany, so effective in its work but so far remote from civilization, I am convinced that you will follow the course most appropriate to the benefit of the school and the advantage of the Department.

Yours very truly,

Joseph [Signature]

Mr. Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Please find enclosed tenders from 3 firms for a complete sawmill installation for Albany Indian Boarding School.

As you are aware a sum of $8,000.00 has been voted at the last Session of Parliament for the transfer and rebuilding of the above school on a better site. It is a matter of prime necessity for the preparation of lumber in view of the construction of the school that a sawmill outfit be sent on the grounds. After the construction of the school it will be kept in use for its benefit.

We had thought at first that a crude-oil engine would be more advantageous but the freighting of oil would entail too much expense. A steam engine is suggested by reason of greater economy and also of greater utility as it could be used later for laundry, heating and other purposes. A boiler of 40 H.P. was needed but the freighting company (Re-villon Freres Trading Co.) has refused to accept such a heavy weight and we have been obliged to consider the purchase of two 20 H.P. Most of the tenders quote on the machines of "La Compagnie Manufacturière F.X. Bertrand" of St Hyacinthe which are of very high standard. Those machines are very well known to Rev. Fr Jodoin O.M.I., who has been active in the field for tenders to cover exactly what is needed in the school.

I take the liberty of stating that Rev. Fr Jodoin strongly recommends Faivre & Laroche's tender above all others. Kindly note that this firm allows 6% discount whilst the others allow only 7%.

As the material must be shipped without delay I would kindly request you to give your immediate attention to this matter and advise me of any decision reached by the Department.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Joseph [Last Name]

OTTAWA, January 10th, 1925

Dear Mr Scott:

For the last few months I have received from His Lordship Bishop Hallé, Rev. Father Villeneuve, Provincial of the Oblate Missionaries, and Rev. Father Carrière O.M.I., Principal of Albany Mission Indian Residential School, what I consider distressing appeals on account of the financial condition of the School and Hospital of Albany Mission, in James Bay.

Following an interview with you in this matter and acting upon your advice, I take the liberty of presenting the case before you, for your personal information and in view of obtaining a substantial help if such is available.

In the course of last month I examined the books of the Provincial Administration of the Oblate Fathers, acting as agents for His Lordship Bishop Hallé, and noticed that they show a deficit of $426.30 in 1923, October 1st of $3087.25 and from January 1st 1924, to October 1st, 1924, an amount of $2456.32, making a total of $7977.87, from January 1st, 1922 to October 1st, 1924. These deficits exist in spite of the Government grants and even though His Lordship and the Oblate Missionaries have literally begged from different quarters and gave to the institution $391.50 (vis: $1934.00 in 1922, $1650.50 in 1923, $1807.00 to October 1924). Of course those last amounts do not include salaries of the Rev. Fathers and Brothers, as they did not receive any. I may even say that the Rev. Fathers and Brothers have gone so far as to work as laborers for the trading Companies, cutting hay for their cattle. The salaries thus earned were simply deducted from the expenses necessitated by the transportation of merchandises for the School.

Some years ago, two of our devoted brothers were drowned and one of our fathers was taken out of the water in an exhausted condition (he has never recovered since) upon arriving from a fishing expedition undertaken for the sole purpose of securing food for the children and staff.

Two years ago, all the merchandises destined to the School were sent to Pagwa, Ont., from Montreal, but lack of water obliged us to ship same back to New Liverpool Town, N.S. by train, thence to Albany by boat, involving an outlay of $1956.32, as vouchers attached readily show.

Three years ago, I obtained from the Department that a sum of $8,000.00 be included in the Esti-
mates, as a contribution for the reconstruction of the School. Of that amount, over $4,000.00 have already been paid for machineries and incidentals. Sad to say, the machineries are still at Pagwa, as lack of water in 1923 and 1924, prevented the Revillon Frères Trading Company from floating down the river, thus delaying them. By the way, I may presently say that special arrangements are being made by the Revillon Frères Trading Company to assure the delivery of the machineries next Spring.

There are on file at the Department, accounts for salaries (with duly signed receipts) to the amount of $2722.00, which are still unpaid. Those salaries cover the cutting of logs, clearing and preparing of land, in view of the construction of a new School building, at a short distance from the present location. The initial expenses and difficulties discouraged the efforts of our men and halted the plans of our Superiors. So the latter inquired into the possibility of making substantial repairs to the present building in order to prolong its duration for a few years. An expert engineer and practical builder was sent from Montreal to Albany, and through his skill and the labour of his two men and our own employees, the existence of the present building has been assured for a few years, pending the intended reconstruction. That work, consisting mainly in the reinforcement and strengthening of the foundations, renewal of floors and draining of surroundings, was carried out at an expense of over $1,700.00 including transportation charges, for which, we did not ask a single penny from the Department.

Moreover, a receipted account from the Bertrand Company of St Hyacinthe, for $412.25, in payment of various pieces and extra parts, in connection with the machineries already paid by the Department, but unfortunately left over at Pagwa, has been refused to be paid by the Department, on the ground that the machineries themselves had not reached Albany Mission. Yet, we have paid for this account, as can be seen on the file at the Department.

Finally, His lordship Bishop Hallé, considering the immense difficulties under which the members of the staff were laboring and the dangers to which they were exposed during their distant expeditions, decided in spite of his poverty, to buy a boat with gasoline engine. To his dismay, he was finally obliged to pay the sum of $4,400.00 to cover the expenses of purchase and freighting of the boat.

Those are a few of the items explaining the reasons of the heavy deficit which is burdening the School of Albany Mission and discouraging the Right Reverend Bishop and his auxiliaries. Yesterday, I was receiving a letter from Rev. Father Carrière, C.S.S., Principal of the School, making known his anxiety; he simply said that bankruptcy is staring at him in the face if the Government does not come to the rescue.

In view of such a situation, I therefore ask, in the name of His Lordship Bishop Hallé, of the Provincial Administration of the Oblate Missionaries and the devoted Fathers, Brothers and Sisters in charge at Albany Mission, that certain accounts above referred to be paid by the Department, in order to allay the financial situation and encourage the staff to continue the carrying
on of their present philanthropic and educational work.

I therefore beg to suggest the payment of the following accounts:

1o-Enclosed vouchers for extra transportation of merchandise in 1923, viz; $463.87 and $432.45.

2o-Accounts for salaries as per statements and receipts on file for the sum of $2722.00. I beg to say that payment of those salaries had been authorised by the Superintendent General approving a Memorandum signed by you and assuring authority for the payment of $2923.92 for such salaries and other items. I would add that I understand that the cleared land is being used for cultivating purposes for the benefit of the school and hospital.

3o-Account for $412.25 from Bertrand & Cie., for exchange pieces and extra parts. This receipted account is on file at the Department.

4o-Accounts for $586.99 and $14.00 from Bournival & Co herewith annexed, for machineries to be used in the shop for repair purposes and piping for the same purposes.

Payment of the above could, in my opinion, be justified, and would prove a boon to the School and practically save it from bankruptcy. You will note that no financial help is requested for the payment of the boat ($4,400.00) nor for the heavy expenses incurred in the making of substantial repairs to the present school building (over $1,700.00) which shows the earnestness of our efforts to cooperate not only morally with the Department, but also financially.

Now, Dear Mr Scott, I leave this whole matter in your hands. You are aware of the extreme difficulties encountered in our Missions of Hudson Bay. Our aim at the Albany Mission School is to civilize the Indians and I can say that our influence is far reaching and therefore is a great factor in the success of the work carried on by your Department.

Hoping that you will give my request a favourable consideration, I remain

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

There has been brought to my attention the serious financial condition of the N. C. Indian Residential School at Albany Mission, James Bay. Transportation costs for this school are very heavy and low water in the Albany river has of late meant some extraordinary charges in this connection.

33,688 pounds of freight were shipped from Montreal to Pauca (west of Hearst) in 1923. The low water in the Albany river held up this huge shipment, which contained their year's supplies, and it was necessary to return 10,884 pounds of food and clothing from Pauca and ship it by steamer to the Hudson's Bay from Liverpool, N. S. 5,160 pounds of machinery, which was not particularly urgent, remained at Pauca and in the fall 9640 pounds of gas and oil, which was fairly urgent, was sent on by snows.

There is on file a receipted account for transportation from Havillan River for £1936.32. $1093.39 was the extra cost of returning the goods from Pauca and shipping them via Liverpool, N. S. I wish to recommend that the Department refund to the school authorities this last amount. This payment would give them some relief in connection with their financial difficulties.

Deputy Superintendent General.

November 25, 1929.

MEMO FOR FILE:

Father Guy and Father Saindon visited the Department today and announced the destruction, by fire, in July of this year, of practically all the materials on the new site of the Albany Indian Residential School. The only equipment which has been supplied by the Department which was saved was the motor. Counting some labour for the excavation, foundation (unsuccessful) a sawmill and the whole of the stone and gravel, the total loss has been approximately $13,000. This does not include the freight on the machinery. The total loss was in the neighbourhood of $20,000, counting the freight costs.

Father Saindon plans to rebuild in 1930 and 1931. At present, there are 10 Brothers getting out logs. The Oblate Fathers were able to purchase a second hand sawmill at a price as yet undetermined; but they require about $2,700 more for machinery and repairs. In addition, there will be required cement coating in the neighbourhood of $1,200; building paper, hardware and finishing material, $5,000; painting inside and outside, etc., $1,000; and finishing, $2,000. They plan to have seven extra Brothers go in next summer to assist with the reconstruction.

The Oblate Fathers are asking the Department for a grant for next year and one for 1931, to assist them in the reconstruction of this school. $10,000 to $12,000 is the figure mentioned as being necessary before they can complete the work.
I have already bought parts of sawmill at the Revillon Freres Trading Company, whose factory is an undetermined price.

For your information I am sending under separate cover photos of the destroyed sawmill and plans of the proposed building which will accommodate 70 children.

The Oblate Missionaries are willing to proceed immediately and assume the necessary responsibilities.

favorable. We hope that all the freight will reach destination

pieces have been cut this past winter.

The Indian Residential School referred to in the enclosed recommendation to Council was commenced by the Oblate Order in 1906, at Albany on the James Bay. During the past few years, they have had 40 to 45 Indian children in residence whose work appears to be well established and of considerable usefulness to the band of Cree Indians on the Bay. The old buildings are no longer suitable and are badly located. A new site has been selected and there has been started a new main building, of frame construction, on a concrete foundation. Plans and specifications were prepared by the Department Architect, to provide for a central heating unit, modern plumbing, sewage disposal and electric light. Accommodation for 50 children is being provided.

The cost of the building will be at least $40,000. The Department has been asked to make grants totalling one-half of the expenditure, and last year, P.C. 86, dated January 16th, last, authorised a first grant of $5,000. The work is being done on a day labour basis, under the supervision of the Church authorities. This year, construction is going forward rapidly - the Church expecting to spend at least $20,000. Authority is required for the payment of a $10,000 grant. The Church authorities will submit receipts showing an expenditure of at least twice this amount this year.

Dear Sir,

... re engines ...

Yours (No. 44-2-5) dated 3rd February re crating and shipping engines, to hand.

It is impossible for us to ship these engines at the present time. In the first place, we are obliged to use the big engine for laundry work as there is no provision made for motors to handle the laundry. Secondly, it is evident that the Spencer plant is in a very poor state of repair and at the present time they are unable to generate enough electricity to handle both this School and the town of Lytton. This fact was discovered only after the line was installed; hence at the moment we are obliged to use our engines to give us light, as heretofore, and until the necessary repairs are made to this generating plant, we shall be obliged to hold our engines in case emergency arises.

Just as soon as we are able to relieve ourselves of the engines, I will inform the Department to this effect, but, at the present time, we cannot do without them.

I trust you will find this explanation satisfactory. - You might from your end bring pressure to bear upon the Spencer Company in hurrying them with their repairs, and also to obtain from them a guarantee of regular service.

Yours very obediently,
