Dear Sir,

... re Electric Generating Plant ...

Yours No. 44-2-5 dated 13th February.

I have been in touch with Colonel Spencer and he feels that within a month's time they will be able to supply the School regularly and without fail so that we shall be able to ship the engines to Winnipeg at that time.

I had not contemplated having to ship the engines as I felt I could not spend the money to change the motors, as it will be necessary, with electric power, to have a motor installed on each of the machines in the laundry. The School cannot at this time meet that expenditure, and I wish you could see what provision could be made in regard to financing this change.

I have written to the laundry people in Vancouver and have held off answering your correspondence hoping that I should have some definite price on this change to forward to you. But to date I have not received same and I felt you would be waiting for some information on the matter.

Colonel Spencer is also taking up the matter of the possible change of the motors with the Company direct in Vancouver; and the delay, no doubt, is due to the fact that they are obliged to get their information direct from the factory in the East.

Cher Monsieur:

Etant au courant de votre connaissance de la langue française, je me permets de vous écrire en français. J'ose croire que vous ne pardonnerez pas facilement cette liberté.

Ainsi que je vous l'ai promis tout dernièrement lorsque je vous visitai au Département, vous trouverez sous même pli quelques photographies de la nouvelle école indienne d'Albany, James-bay, Ontario. Ces photos vous donneront une idée du travail déjà fait en attendant que vous puissiez, en juger par vous-même, puisque nous aurons l'honneur et le plaisir d'avoir votre visite l'an prochain. Je dirais en passant qu'il puisse se faire qu'il me soit possible de vous conduire moi-même à Albany; cela toutefois si vous n'avez aucun autre arrangement dans ce sens.

Le but de cette lettre est de vous mettre au courant de notre difficulté financière. Ce sont des doléances que vous savez entendre bien sourire depuis que vous êtes entré au Département, mais cela ne doit pas, il me semble, me tenir de vous exposer notre embarras. La construction de cette école est d'une grande importance puisque c'est la seule école indienne pensionnat de toute la province. Les Indiens de Wenonah, Opinaw, Attawapiskat y envoient leurs enfants, soit d'une distance de 300 milles. Il nous en arrive parfois de Port-Hope, d'Ogoki.

C'est à travers mille difficultés que nous construisons à cause de la distance et ces circonstances de lieu où nous nous trouvons, car il nous faut aller chercher les matériaux à une grande distance. Il y a actuellement 12 Frères Coadjuteurs attachés à cette mission, et occupés à la construction.

Nous avons installé une scierie mécanique à vapeur pour préparer le bois nécessaire à cet établissement, mais malheureusement cette scierie a été incendiée en 1928. Nous avons dû la remplacer par une autre qui actuellement nous rend de grands services et diminue considérablement le coût de la construction. Cet incendie cependant nous a considérablement retardé dans la marche des travaux.

Le corps central de l'école est actuellement habité. Le système de chauffage qui consiste en une irradiation de vapeur à basse pression est actuellement en fonction. L'électricité est aussi installée.

Cette école pourra recevoir 100 enfants quand elle sera terminée. Elle coûtera approximativement $125,000.00.
Après entente verbale avec le regretté B.T. Ferrier, surintendant des Écoles indiennes la moitié des dépenses devaient être fournies par le Département. Quinze mille dollars nous ont déjà été payés. Dix mille dollars nous avaient été promis pour l'année dernière, mais cette approbation a été renouvelée. Me flançant à cette somme que j'étais dans le cas de recevoir, parce que je ne me suis jamais été notifié de l'octroi de celui-là, j'ai acheté tout le matériel pour poursuivre les travaux et rendre l'école habitable. Les dépenses se chiffrent à près de 12000.00 cette année au total de 12000.00 pour l'année dernière.

Il est à noter que je n'ai pu rembourser les frais de la dépression actuelle. Vous comprendrez vous-même que les secours advenant de la charité sont presque totalement taris.

Cependant, il nous faut continuer le travail commencé, parce que, en discontinue, une foule de matériaux serait perdus. Mais nous ne pouvons aller plus loin sans secours, parce que nous avons l'allocation accordée à l'école nous permet tout juste de vivre avec la plus grande économie. Le personnel de l'école est pauvre et il faut le soutenir. Tous mes missionnaires sont sans aucun salaire, ni rétribution. Nous sommes heureux de faire notre part dans cette œuvre de civilisation, mais, vous le comprenez, il nous faut le soutien de la vie.

Nous donnons notre entière coopération au Département pour cette école et nous espérons que le secours nécessaire ne nous sera pas refusé. Je le sais, votre Département est lié par la crise actuelle et il vous est difficile de répondre à toutes les demandes et à tous les besoins; toutefois, je serais heureux d'attirer votre attention sur mon grand embarras financier.

Il me faudrait acheter certains matériaux qui seront transportés l'été prochain, mais dans les circonstances je n'ose le faire. Je passerai au Département vers la fin de mars et je vous communiquerai plus de précisions sur ce dernier point.

Je souhaite que vous puissiez trouver quelques milliers de Dollars, comme vous le désirez vous-même, pour nous aider à solder une partie de la dette.

J'aime à croire que ces quelques renseignements vous seront utiles et vous mettront au courant de notre situation.

Je vous remercie d'avance de ce que vous ferez pour nous et veuillez me croire, Monsieur le Docteur,

Votre tout dévoué,

T.E. Sanderson, o.m.i.,

Moosonee, James Bay, Ontario,
December 2, 1932.

Doctor McGill, Deputy Minister,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Booth House, Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

Being aware of your knowledge of the French language,
I take the liberty of writing in French, I dare hope you will
pardon me that liberty.

As I promised you sometime ago when I visited you at
the Department, you will find under cover a few photographs of
the new Indian School at Albany, James Bay, Ontario. These
photographs will give you an idea of the work already done, un-
til you can judge for yourself, since we will have the honour
and the pleasure of your visit next Summer. I may say that it
might be possible for me to take you myself to Albany; that is
if you have another engagement at the time.

The object of this letter is to inform you of our
financial difficulties. These are complaints you must hear
quite often since your arrival at the Department, but that
must not, it seems to me, prevent my explanation of our em-
barrassing situation. The construction of that school is of
great importance since it is the only Indian Boarding School
of the whole West Coast. The Indians of Weenisk, Opengow,
Attawapiskat send their children there, being at a distance
of 300 miles. We sometimes receive pupils from Fort Hope
and Ogoki.

It is through a thousand difficulties that we build
on account of the distance and the circumstances of our loca-
tion, because we have to get our material from a considerable
distance. There are at present 12 co-adjutor brothers attach-
ed to this Mission, and busy with the construction.

We had installed a steam lumber saw mill to prepare
the necessary timber for that building, but unfortunately that
saw mill was burnt down in 1928. We have to replace it by
another which at present renders us great services and dimin-
ishes the cost of the construction. That fire has, however,
delayed the course of the work considerably.

The central part of the school is now fit to dwell
in. The heating system which consists of low pressure steam
radiation is now functioning. Electricity is also installed.
This school could receive 100 children when it is completed. It will cost approximately $125,000.00.

After a verbal agreement with the regretted Mr. R. T. Ferrier, late Superintendent of Indian Schools, one half of the expenditure was to be provided by his Department. We have already been paid fifteen thousand dollars. Ten thousand dollars was promised us for last year, but that appropriation was cancelled. Relaying on this sum, which I was certain to receive because I was never notified it had been cut off, I purchased all the material to continue the work and render the school habitable. The expenditure will amount to about $12,000.00 this year and more than that for last year.

I had to borrow that sum and I could not reimburse it on account of the present depression. You will conceive for yourself that the relief coming from charitable sources are almost totally exhausted.

Nevertheless, we must continue the work started, because if it was discontinued, a number of materials would be lost. But we cannot go any farther without help, because the grant given to the school allows us barely a living with the strictest economy. The staff of the school is numerous and we have to sustain it. All my Missionaries are without salaries or remuneration. We are happy to do our part in this task of civilization, but you will understand, our livelihood is to be sustained.

We give our entire co-operation to the Department for this school and we hope that the necessary help will not be refused. I know that your Department is bound by the present crisis and it is difficult to answer to all the requests and all needs; however, may I be permitted to draw your attention on my great financial perplexity.

I would have to purchase certain material which will be brought over next Summer, but under the circumstances I dare not do it. I shall be at the Department at the end of March next and I will communicate with you more precisely on that last point.

I wish that you may find a few thousand dollars as you wish it yourself, to help us to settle a portion of the debt.

I like to believe that this information will be useful to you, and will acquaint you with our situation.

I thank you in advance for what you may do for us and believe me, Dear Doctor.

Yours devotedly

(Sgd.) T. R. Saindon, O.M.I.,
Vic.-provincial.
herewith.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

The session is opening in a few weeks and it is about the time that appropriations are voted for different Departments. As it is not probable that I will be given the occasion of residing in Ottawa before that time I have thought advisable to send you the estimate of expenditures for the coming financial year at the Albany Residential School.

To complete the school it would be very much appreciated if an appropriation of $10,000.00 could be granted. The following material is to be bought:

1.- Fire protection is to be secured, the equipment consists in fire escape stairs, a small motor with a pump and hoses.
2.- As only country lumber is had and such wood is not suitable for interior finishing it is desirable that the interior be completed with some other material. We intend to buy 50,000 feet of cypress.
3.- The electrical and heating plants have to be completed.
4.- Nails, glass, paint, etc., are to be needed.
5.- Furnitures are also badly wanted as classroom desks, teachers' desks, chairs, blackboards and other articles.
6.- Indian labour will be required.
7.- Freight for this supply has to be figured.

It is expected that the yearly expenditure shall amount to approximately $12,000.00.

The late R.T. Perrier had promised to grant the amount of $6,000.00 towards the building of the Albany School. Fifteen thousand have already been paid. Twenty thousand are still to be paid on the principal bought. Money has been borrowed at the rate of six per cent.

An appropriation of $10,000.00 had been expected for the past financial year, but owing to circumstances the appropriation was not voted. We would be very grateful to the Department if $6,000.00 is granted this year. I think that if such allowance is granted we will not need any further help.

The construction has begun in 1928, but owing to great difficulties the work could not be done in less time than we have done it. We are very anxious to see the establishment completed. We already have demand for more children than we can receive at the present time.
the school is completed 100 children could be put up easily.

If I bring stress on the subject of the grant you will easily understand it is on account of the hard times we all have to pass through. We have tried to economize as much as it was possible. All the work has been done by the Brothers who do not touch any remuneration.

When the building is completed we expect that the Department will be pleased with it, because it is built according to regulations and on a modern plan approved by the Department.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

While in Albany I inspected the R.C. Res. School building and classes.

The building is far from finished; it is still in a rough state both inside and out. The stairs are temporary and the two fire escapes are temporary and built of wood. I would advise that the fire escapes be changed at once.

There are two class-rooms with a teacher in charge of each. The present class rooms are small but I believe these are to be moved to other rooms when they are completed. The pupils are divided into four grades: the two senior grades in one room and the juniors in the other.

I consider that the children in the respective grades are doing fairly well and are being taught to speak and write English as well as Cree. The children are well advanced in Arithmetic, Reading, Writing and Spelling; they read from sight and not from memory.

The greatest fault I find is that the children will not speak out, and that you have difficulty getting them to answer questions although they know the answer; this is a common fault with all the Indians in this Agency and seems to be due to their shyness.

Yours truly,

W.L. Tyre Agent.

Dear Sir,

The Principal of the Albany Residential School in a report of the construction of the school is stressing that the activities should be resumed at that point, this coming Summer, and that necessary improvements should be made.

He is, in the same time, requisitioning a certain quantity of building materials such as wall paper, nails, glass, electrical equipment, boiler tubes, radiators, fire escapes, etc.

The above mentioned articles are most necessary. In fact, the school would require an outside lining to strengthen the frame; the floors are single and need doubling to prevent the dampness to come up from the cellar; the ceilings are only temporary; storm windows should also be had; hot water system would also be most appreciated, at least, in some apartments.

Report of the conditions at the Albany Residential School was made to the Oblate Board and a grant to carry on the work was asked, but the answer of the Board is the following: "We have financed the construction as far as $10,000 were contributed with the understanding that the Department would reimburse that amount, which has not yet been done and the money is tied up without interest. We are ready to co-operate to the limit of our abilities and to carry the heaviest part of the burden, but we regret to say that, owing to present economic circumstances, we cannot go any farther."

I had hoped that through the strictest economy we could squeeze a few hundred dollars on the regular allocations to carry on the work during this coming Summer, but the crops were spoiled by early frosts, the fishing, due to the early coming of the winter, also failed. Consequently, expenses are running higher than it had been expected and no credit balance shall be left.

I am honestly at a lost about the means which should be taken to go ahead with the construction which really needs being carried on.

It would be deeply appreciated by the Oblate Fathers that the $10,000 would be reimbursed. The co-operation of the Department to carry on the necessary improvements would be also highly appraised.

The aforesaid improvements would amount to approximately $5,000.

This is the present situation which I have thought of my duty to bring to your attention, trusting that it is only by the mutual co-operation of both parties that a betterment can be contemplated for the coming year at the Albany Residential School.

Yours sincerely,

His Excellency
The Governor General in Council,

The undersigned has the honour to refer to Orders of Your Excellency in Council, P.C. 86, dated the 16th of January, 1931; and P.C. 2502, dated the 13th of October, 1931—copies of which are attached hereto—authorizing payment to the total amount of $15,000.00 by the Department of Indian Affairs towards the cost of construction of a Roman Catholic Indian Residential School, conducted under the auspices of the Oblate Order, at Albany, on James Bay, in the province of Ontario.

The building, of frame construction, on a concrete foundation, was erected during the years 1930 and 1931. It is heated by central units, has modern plumbing and sewage disposal and electric light systems.

Plans and specifications for the building were prepared by the Architect of the Department. Accommodation for one hundred pupils is provided.

In view of the remote location of Albany, it was considered advisable to have the building constructed on a day labour basis, under the supervision of the Oblate Order, who were in a position to secure economic labour and arrange for freighting of materials at minimum cost.

The Oblate Order expended, approximately, the sum of $60,000.00 in carrying out the work and have been reimbursed by the Department to the amount of $15,000.00, as authorised by Orders in Council above mentioned.

The authorities of the Oblate Order have made repeated requests for further remuneration towards the expenditure incurred by them in the construction of the building.

As final payment of the Department's obligation, the sum of $6,000.00 is provided in the Estimates for Indian Education for the fiscal year 1934-35.

The undersigned accordingly has the honour to recommend that authority be granted for the expenditure of the said sum of $6,000.00 for the purpose above mentioned.

Superintendent General
